chapter.title: Summary of Findings - Stakeholder Feedback on Kowledge Management Use Cases (Months 13-24)

section.title: Purpose
section.para: Health Information Technology (IT) is pivotal for organizing, analyzing, and exchanging patient health information. Despite its potential to ease provider workload and enhance patient care, current clinical decision support systems exhibit inconsistencies that can adversely impact both patients and providers. A significant challenge lies in the lack of uniform encoding standards, which impedes lab data interoperability due to errors and inconsistencies in data transfers. The use of varying health data standards across different stages of the patient care lifecycle further complicates the delivery of care, as providers struggle with transitioning information between systems. This complexity is exacerbated by the diverse ways in which healthcare information is collected, stored, and exchanged, making it difficult to maintain data consistency as it moves between care providers.

Thus, an integrated knowledge management framework is needed to unify all knowledge resources under a common representation. This framework facilitates version control, standardized viewing, collaborative editing, and extension development, enabling the creation of shared knowledge bases. These knowledge bases not only streamline laboratory data but also simplify the relationships across disparate knowledge standards by extracting and representing common elements uniformly.

section.title: Objective
section.para: This document is intended to serve as a summary of major feedback received from key relevant parties on the prototype Integrated Knowledge Management (IKM) framework. This feedback was collected and synthesized from a variety of interviews conducted over the previous period aimed at the comprehension and digestibility of IKM.

To gauge current opinions, receptivity, and general understanding of the IKM framework and use-cases developed, the team compiled feedback from a number of relevant parties in a variety of forums, most notably:

listitem.para: The relevant party interview provided valuable insights into the concept authoring process and user interface of a tool. The interviewee demonstrated a clear understanding of the tool's functionalities but noted confusion with certain manual selections and complex features, suggesting potential cognitive load issues. They emphasized the importance of a structured workflow and collaboration, preferring to complete tasks in one sitting to maintain focus. Challenges were identified in the validation and classification processes, as well as difficulties with editing due to non-intuitive interface elements. Although the tool's design and familiar interactions were appreciated, significant issues with terminology, icon usability, and navigation were highlighted.

The relevant party interviews with clinical informaticists provided valuable feedback on the Knowledge Management Environment (Komet) tool's interface and functionality. They appreciated the improved design and usability over previous versions but stressed the need for clearer terminology and contextual guidance, particularly for new users. The informaticists emphasized the importance of intuitive search features, module awareness, and efficient navigation and editing of concepts. They also noted the complexity of certain features, such as the "patterns" concept, and called for better visual hierarchy and tooltips. Overall, while the enhancements were positively received, the feedback highlighted the need for continued improvements in user guidance and interface clarity to better support clinical informatics workflows.

section.title: Methodology
section.para: To assess the Next Gen Komet Authoring Environment, we conducted two rounds of remote, individual interviews with expert users. Each session, lasting between 60 and 75 minutes, were structured around task-based evaluations, where participants engaged with an interactive Figma prototype. They were encouraged to verbalize their thoughts as they navigated the interface, providing insights into their mental models and identifying usability challenges. The facilitator monitored their interactions, offering guidance when necessary and demonstrating features when the prototype's limitations restricted direct engagement.

During these sessions, we collected a wide array of feedback, including areas of confusion, initial impressions, and responses to terminology and workflows. Participants also provided spontaneous suggestions and ideas, enriching the feedback. The research was supported by tools such as Figma for the prototype experience, Zoom for facilitation and screen sharing, and live notetaking alongside session recordings (with participant consent) to ensure comprehensive documentation of insights.

section.title: Common Feedback Themes
section.para: To create actionable insights from the questions, comments, and concerns that were brought up during these engagements, the team has categorized them into the following themes: ‘Workspace Interaction and Usability’, ‘Search and Navigation Functionalities’, and ‘Concepts’.

section.title: Workspace Interaction and Usability
section.para: Workspace Interaction and Usability is the initial touchpoint for users engaging with Komet, playing a crucial role in shaping their first impressions and overall experience. It encompasses design, module and path selection, application navigation, and concept management. Effective usability ensures that users can navigate the system intuitively, enhancing satisfaction and productivity. Below is the feedback from relevant parties following a recent demonstration.

listitem.para: Module nd Path Importance: The importance of module and path selection in setting up authoring work was emphasized, with appreciation for interface improvements like clearer module dropdowns.
Tooltip and Icon Clarity: The addition of hover tooltips was appreciated, but some icons (e.g., Validator or Coordinate) were found to be non-intuitive or unclear.
Notes vs. Comments: There was a suggestion to merge or clarify Notes and Comments and improve visual hierarchy for better clarity.
Module Switching Clarity: Users demonstrated a mental model for Sandbox → Development → Production but wanted more clarity on module switching and indicators for the current module.
Lucidchart Comparison: The workspace view reminded users of Lucidchart, leading to expectations for zooming, panning, dragging, and visual canvas interactions.

Navigation Intuitiveness: While navigation gestures like zoom and list toggling were intuitive, some buttons (e.g., top-right arrow) were unclear due to small size or missing labels. The prototype lacked full interactivity, but users assumed the intended behavior correctly, indicating sound design but weak User Interface (UI) cues.

Concept Management: Users questioned whether having many concepts open was beneficial or distracting, seeking clarity on what’s “active” versus “in progress.” This raises design questions worth exploring for workspace management.

section.title: Key Takeaways
section.para: Based on the feedback received from relevant parties regarding Concept, the team has compiled key takeaways:

listitem.para: Module and Path Selection Enhancements: The improvements in module and path selection, such as clearer dropdowns and hover tooltips, were well-received. However, there is a need for better clarity and intuitiveness in icon design, particularly for icons like Validator and Coordinate. Additionally, users suggested merging or clarifying the distinction between Notes and Comments to improve visual hierarchy and understanding. There is also a desire for clearer indicators and understanding of module switching, especially in the context of transitioning from Sandbox to Development and Production environments.

Workspace Interaction and Concept Management: Users appreciated the intuitive navigation gestures reminiscent of Lucidchart, such as zooming and panning, but noted that some UI elements, like small or unlabeled buttons, could be improved for better usability. The feedback highlighted a need to explore the design of workspace management, particularly regarding the handling of multiple open concepts and distinguishing between "active" and "in progress" states. This indicates an opportunity to refine workspace interactions to enhance user satisfaction and productivity.

section.title: Search and Navigation Functionalities
section.para: The "Search and Navigation Functionalities" section is pivotal in ensuring users can efficiently locate and access the information they need within Komet. By providing intuitive search options and seamless navigation paths, this area enhances user experience, reduces time spent on tasks, and boosts overall productivity. Below is the feedback from relevant parties regarding these functionalities following a recent demonstration.

listitem.para: Real Estate Concerns: Users found the duplicated listing of display names and fully qualified names in search results to be space-consuming without providing additional value.
Sorting Confusion: The distinction between “Top Component” and “Matched Description Semantic” was unclear, with alphabetical sorting being the only consistently useful option.
Workflow Importance: Search is central to users' workflows, primarily used to determine if a new concept is needed or if an existing one can be extended.
Exact Match Issues: There was criticism that exact matches do not always appear at the top of search results.
Active vs. Retired Concepts: Users want the default search results to show only active concepts, with an option to toggle and review retired concepts for historical insight.
Terminology Confusion: Terms like “top component,” “matched description,” and “semantic” were confusing, leading users to experiment by clicking around to understand sorting methods.
Discoverability Issues: Users found the module filter only through a process of elimination, suggesting a need for clearer labels or inline guidance.

Visual Confusion: The visual representation of hierarchy was unclear, with questions about the meaning behind the angles of lines and the presence of circles. There was difficulty in understanding how polyhierarchy and multi-parenting were depicted.
Polyhierarchial Expections: There was an expectation for polyhierarchy to display all parent paths, but it seemed that only one path was shown, leading to confusion.

Navigation Needs: There is a desire for a visual Systematized Nomenclature of Medicine (SNOMED®) hierarchy that allows users to easily navigate parent-child relationships without needing to know exact terms.
Logical Subdivisions: Chapters are seen as logical subdivisions within a project, organizing content into categories like Obstetrics and Gynecology (OB-GYN) or cardiology.
Hierarchy Interpretation: Users accurately interpreted Project Journals as large workspaces or initiatives, with Chapters as sub-tasks or topic-specific workstreams.
Completion Matching: Users strongly recommended implementing completion matching, such as typing "tet fal" to return "Tetralogy of Fallot."
Favorites Feature: The idea of marking frequently used concepts as favorites was well-received.
Screen Space Concerns: The "description semantics" panel in search results was seen as taking up too much screen space, distracting from important tasks like reviewing axiom relationships.

section.title: Key Takeaways
section.para: Based on the feedback received from relevant parties regarding Search and Navigation Functionalities, the team has compiled key takeaways:

listitem.para: Search and Sorting Challenges: Users face confusion and inefficiencies with the current search and sorting functionalities. Issues include the unclear distinction between sorting options like "Top Component" and "Matched Description Semantic," and the lack of prioritization for exact matches in search results. Additionally, the duplicated display of names and fully qualified names is seen as unnecessary and space-consuming. Users also expressed a need for the default search to focus on active concepts, with an option to view retired ones.

Hierarchy and Navigation improvements: The visual representation of hierarchies is unclear, causing confusion about polyhierarchical structures and navigation paths. Users expect a more intuitive display of parent-child relationships and logical subdivisions within projects. The current system's inability to clearly show all parent paths in polyhierarchies and the lack of a user-friendly visual SNOMED® hierarchy are significant areas for improvement. Additionally, clearer labels or inline guidance for filters and navigation tools are needed to enhance discoverability and user experience.

section.title: Concepts
section.para: The "Concepts" section is integral to managing and understanding the complex data structures within Komet. It includes Change History/Version Control, Axiom Visibility and Concept Management, Relationship Modeling, and Terminology. These functionalities ensure accurate tracking of changes, clear visibility into data structures, and effective management of relationships and terminology. Together, they enhance data integrity and facilitate informed decision-making. Below is the feedback from relevant parties regarding these functionalities following a recent demonstration.

listitem.para: Version Tracking Appeal: Users appreciated the concept of version tracking across time and extensions, noting it as superior to current tools.
Timeline Clarity: Users struggled to understand changes in the timeline and how to interpret green dots and labels.
Comparison Needs: There is a desire for side-by-side comparisons and clearer visual cues to highlight differences.
Appreciation for Functionality: The feature was described as "slick" for comparing changes, especially for evolving concepts.
Collaboration Use Case: It is particularly useful when multiple people are collaborating or editing a term, such as when a graduate student makes changes.
Color Coding: Users liked the ability to see edits across different extensions, such as SNOMED® Clinical Terminology (CT), US Extension, and Primordial Path, through color coding.
Content Specificity: The feature is seen as clever and potentially useful, particularly for user-authored content rather than standardized terms.
Screen Real Estate: It was suggested that the feature should collapse by default to avoid occupying too much screen space.
Overuse Concers: For long-established SNOMED® content, the feature may not always be necessary, but it is potentially more beneficial for user-created content.
Intuitive Navigation: While users appreciated the potential to compare across extensions like SNOMED® and Logical Observation Identifiers, Names, and Codes (LOINC®), the process was not intuitive.
Axiom Display: Users appreciated the prominent and clean display of axioms, considering it a significant improvement in the interface.
Duplication Feature: The ability to duplicate a concept was valued as a shortcut for authoring related content efficiently.

Concept Editing: Users believe that editing a Fully Qualified Name should be restricted to user-authored content, not SNOMED® originals. The interaction of clicking directly into the name field was seen as innovative but not immediately obvious.
Children Concepts View: There was an expectation to view children of a concept within the same interface or have easy navigation options to access them.

"Is-a" Relationship: Establishing an “Is-a” relationship early in the modeling process was deemed crucial, with users typically starting by defining a parent relationship before adding more complex logic or attributes.

Necessary vs. Sufficient Sets: Users generally do not distinguish between necessary and sufficient sets, preferring to focus on what is both necessary and sufficient. The UI's requirement for explicit axiom type selection was questioned, as SNOMED® determines whether a concept is primitive or fully defined by logic.
Advanced User Needs: While separating necessary and sufficient sets might benefit advanced users, most modelers do not require this complexity.
Property Set Unfamiliarity: The term “property set” was unfamiliar, with speculation that it might refer to a template or reusable pattern for defining concepts.

Parent Concept Selection: Users emphasized the need for clearer cues and better semantic context when selecting parent concepts, especially in distinguishing between similar categories like congenital diseases or anomalies.

section.title: Key Takeaways
section.para: Based on the feedback received from relevant parties regarding Concept, the team has compiled key takeaways:

listitem.para: Change History and Version Control Enhancements: The "Time Travel Feature" for version tracking is highly appreciated for its ability to track changes across time and extensions, offering superior functionality compared to existing tools. However, users face challenges with timeline clarity and interpreting visual cues like green dots and labels. There is a strong desire for side-by-side comparisons and clearer visual indicators to highlight differences. While the feature is beneficial for collaborative editing and user-authored content, concerns about screen space and intuitive navigation remain, suggesting areas for improvement.

Axiom Visibilty and Relatinship Modeling Needs: Users value the clean display of axioms and the ability to duplicate concepts for efficient authoring. However, there is a need for clearer interaction cues, especially for editing Fully Qualified Names, which should be restricted to user-authored content. In relationship modeling, establishing an “Is-a” relationship early is crucial, but the distinction between necessary and sufficient sets is not commonly made by users, indicating a potential simplification of the UI. Additionally, clearer semantic cues are needed for parent concept selection to aid users in distinguishing between similar categories.

section.title: Conclusion
section.para: The feedback gathered from key relevant parties on the IKM framework provides valuable insight for refining future iterations of the prototype. Relevant parties, including representatives from the University of Nebraska Medical Center and clinical informaticists, highlighted both strengths and areas for improvement in the framework. The feedback underscored the need for a more intuitive user interface and clearer terminology to reduce cognitive load and enhance user experience. The reviewers praised the framework's design and usability improvements but emphasized the necessity of structured workflows and collaborative features to facilitate efficient task completion. The identification of challenges in validation and classification processes, as well as navigation difficulties, illuminate the need for ongoing enhancements to support seamless user interaction.

This feedback is instrumental in driving the iterative development process of the IKM framework. By addressing the highlighted issues, such as the complexity of certain features and the need for better visual hierarchy and tooltips, the development team can enhance the framework's usability and functionality. Ultimately, feedback gathered will lead to a more robust and user-friendly IKM framework that effectively unifies knowledge resources, streamlines laboratory data, and simplifies the integration of disparate knowledge standards, thereby improving data consistency and interoperability in healthcare settings.
